Introduction
This user guide has been written to support all clinical users of the pathology services provided by and on behalf of Broomfield Hospital.

The guidance document is written to support all Trust and local Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) staff wishing to use the services offered by the Trust Pathology departments. The document is designed to provide information on how best to contact the departments or request their services and provides an outline of the current test repertoire available
Equality impact assessment
Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust is committed to the provision of a
service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 10).
Staffing and training

The Pathology Service is overseen by the Clinical Director who is the accountable manager to the Trust. Each laboratory within the directorate has a designated consultant lead, who alongside their medical or clinical scientist team, provides advice on the interpretation of results, further investigations and treatments.
The clinical leads oversee the analytical diagnostic service which is provided by Health and Care Professions Council registered Biomedical Scientists and Health Care Assistants.
All staff groups undertake regular training and competency assessment with those professionally registered required to maintain an on-going portfolio of continuing professional development.
Only individuals who have received appropriate training and been assessed as competent should undertake phlebotomy procedures.
Only those staff observed as competent to National Patient Safety Agency standards may take blood for transfusion purposes.
Infection prevention

Standard infection prevention measures should be applied when undertaking venepuncture techniques and processes involving the handling of biological material. Hand hygiene should be paramount and where necessary extra precautions taken (e.g. barrier nursed patients and blood culture collection).
Information governance

The Pathology department take the management of all personal information seriously and any breaches of the department's policy will be acted upon. A copy of the department's policy for Management of Data and Information (PATH-IT-PY-
1) is available upon request.
Complaints and feedback

The Pathology department strives to provide a quality service to our users and patients. Should the department not meet your requirements as a user, the department would encourage you to contact the individual laboratory in the first instance. If they are unable to resolve your query, please speak to the relevant Clinical / Laboratory Lead. In the unlikely event that the department is still unable to resolve your concern, please contact either the pathology service manager or pathology clinical director.

In addition to wanting to resolve your concerns, the departments are always eager to receive feedback when the service exceeds your expectations, and would encourage you to contact the individual laboratories with your comments, where these will be logged and feedback given to the relevant members of staff.
General information
Broomfield Hospital

7.1.1 Broomfield Hospital provides hospital care for a population in excess of 380,000. A Pathology service is provided for the acute and the local Clinical Commissioning Groups to support clinical practice by offering access to services that are essential in the diagnosis, management and treatment of disease.
Pathology Department
7.2.1 The Pathology department is divided into seven areas which incorporate:-
Biochemistry;
Blood Sciences Specimen Reception and Office;
Cellular Pathology including Histology, Non-Gynaecological Cytology and Mortuary;
Haematology including Blood Transfusion;
Immunology;
Microbiology;
Phlebotomy.

7.2.2 All the laboratories offer a comprehensive analytical service. However for some specialised and low volume assays, specimens will be referred for analysis to either specialist laboratories or centres of excellence.

data.text: Laboratory hours
Routine hours
10.1.1  All laboratories and Pathology departments will operate a full service during their routine working hours.
Saturday morning service
10.2.1  The Saturday morning service is for semi-routine work only and tests available are limited to the on-call repertoire for participating laboratories.
Out of hours service
10.3.1 An on-call service is in operation for the following departments outside of those times listed above:
Biochemistry;
Haematology;
Microbiology;
Mortuary.
Blood Sciences Reception (09:00 – 17:00)
10.3.2 Samples for Cellular Pathology outside of the times described in section 10.1 should be taken to the Pathology Reception (D228) and placed in the appropriate boxes on the counter.

10.3.3 One Health and Care Professions Council registered Biomedical Scientists for each laboratory is contactable via switchboard to provide an ‘urgent only' analytical service to assist in the immediate management of the patients care.
10.3.4 Phlebotomy offers an urgent only Broomfield in-patient venepuncture service on Sunday and Bank Holiday mornings between 7:30 – 10:30. Requests forms must be received before 7am.
10.3.5 A mortuary APT can be contacted via switchboard.
Urgent requests

During normal laboratory working hours contact the laboratory directly to ensure priority processing of urgent requests. Wherever possible, agreed urgent samples are processed individually as soon as the sample reaches the laboratory. Such requests should be limited to tests required for immediate diagnosis or therapy.
Urgent Histology samples should arrive before 15:00 hours.

Outside normal working hours contact should be made via switchboard to inform those departments offering an on-call service that their service is required, or the laboratory on call member of staff should be bleeped.

The Microbiology on call service is restricted to certain specimen types, these are: CSF (at all times) and corneal scrapes and joint fluids (only up until 10:00 at night). If you wish to arrange for any other urgent requests for microbiological analysis you must contact the Duty Consultant Microbiologist.
All requests for the Microbiological examination of CSF samples must be treated as urgent and the department informed of the sample being sent.
Request forms
General guidance

12.1.1 The request form is a contract, by completing the form the requestor is confirming consent for the sample being taken. A request form must accompany all specimens sent to the laboratory. Each request accepted by the laboratory shall be considered an agreement.

12.1.2 There are a number of different Pathology request forms in use; use the correct form and fill in the details clearly. If using patient data labels fill in ward/location, sex and consultant boxes for result destinations, to ensure that results are sent
back to the correct location and clinician. All forms should be accompanied by appropriate clinical information.
12.1.3 The request form should clearly state the following information:
Hospital number and/or NHS number;
Patient surname and first name;
Date of birth;
Sex;
Patient location;
(Ward/GP name and number/address for report);
Requesting doctor's name and bleep;
Consultant;
Type of specimen (anatomical site if appropriate);
Date and time specimen taken (include serial times for dynamic testing);
Name of the person collecting the specimen;
Tests required;
All relevant clinical details (relevant to or affecting sample collection; examination performance or result interpretation (e.g. history of administration of drugs);
Patient's status e.g. fasting where appropriate.

12.1.4 The Broomfield Hospital order communication system produces labels to be attached to the request form and barcodes for all required specimen types. The system is designed to ensure that all required information is requested prior to the labels being printed. Please follow the instructions on the request form for attaching labels.

12.1.5 It should be noted that if there is a strong index of suspicion of a patient having a notifiable infectious disease the clinician responsible for the patient's treatment has a duty of care under the Health and Safety legislation to inform other healthcare professionals. In practical terms this means that the testing laboratory should be informed when samples have been collected to allow appropriate reception of the samples in the laboratory. Additionally, the specimen request form must contain full and appropriate clinical details.
Group and cross-match requests
12.2.1 Patient data labels must not be used on group and cross-match requests.
12.2.2 All patient information must be completed correctly by hand and must include the following information:
A clear clinical requirement for blood or blood products;
Time and date of when the blood or blood products are required;
Relevant patient specific special requirements, e.g. CMV negative or irradiated blood products.
12.2.3 All specimens and request forms must be signed by the collector of the patients' sample. Refer to the Request form for more detailed information.
12.2.4 A zero tolerance policy is in operation for any incomplete or incorrect specimen and forms received. Specimens will be discarded and the requesting location informed.
Microbiology
12.3.1 To support the clinical interpretation and intervention advice provided by the Microbiology consultants the following information must also be provided:
Clinical details, including any anti-microbial treatment (recent, current and intended) and foreign travel;
Date of onset and duration of illness, particularly for serology;
Anatomical site from which ‘wound' specimen taken;
Useful epidemiological information, e.g. date of contact, if relevant.
12.3.2 Unlabelled, mislabelled and specimens received without a microbiology specimen request form will not be examined.
12.3.3 If there is any clinical suspicion of infection with Hazard Group 3 Pathogens (e.g. M.Tuberculosis) this MUST be indicated on the sample request form.
Pathology consumables

Pathology consumables can be ordered through our Pathology Stores service at mse.pathology.stores@nhs.net  using the designated requisition forms. This includes blood bottles, sample pots, requests forms, specimen bags etc. Please email all queries and requests to the designated email address. Requisitions can be hand delivered to Pathology Reception D228.
Blood collection
Health and safety guidance

13.1.1 All staff are required to take reasonable care for their own safety and that of others who might be affected by their acts or omissions at work. All specimens must be packaged and transported to Pathology in accordance with ‘Transport of Pathology Specimens' Register Number  The person dispatching the specimens is responsible for this; Pathology only assumes responsibility for specimens when they arrive in the laboratory.

13.1.2 Hands should be washed and antibacterial gel used before and after taking any samples and gloves should be worn. A universal precaution policy should be adopted, that all biological samples should be treated as potentially hazardous. Please make sure all containers are securely capped and placed in self-sealing packages. Request forms should not come into contact with the sample at any stage.
13.1.3 Only those staff observed as competent to National Patient Safety Agency standards may take blood for transfusion purposes.
13.1.4 Instructions for safe venepuncture are available from the phlebotomy service; you should:
Minimise handling of needles;
Follow correct practice and discard needles directly into a sharps container.

13.1.5 If possible, delay the taking of blood samples for  hours after injection of radioisotope. If sampling cannot be delayed then wear gloves during all handling of the sample and label with a “radioactive sticker”. Please contact the appropriate department for further advice and if urgent processing is required
General points to note

13.2.1 There are many problems that can arise due to poor phlebotomy technique or failure to follow procedures. These create a risk not only to the patient but also for the Trust. Only individuals who have been given training and assessed as competent should perform phlebotomy procedures.

13.2.2 Where ever possible, use the Trust adopted collection system. Pathology regularly receives samples that are haemolysed, clotted, or contaminated by EDTA from a blood count bottle, which means that the sample cannot be processed as, if analysed, may produce an erroneous result.

13.2.3 Common causes of errors include collecting blood using a syringe and needle and then filling each tube from the syringe without necessarily removing the needle, excessive shaking or touching the inside of the tube with the syringe tip (the latter leading to contamination).
13.2.4 Use of the collection system, together with the recommended order of draw, followed by gentle inversion, is the best way of ensuring sample stability.

13.5.1 The BioMerieux BacT/ALERT Microbial Detection System is used to determine if micro-organisms  are  present in  the  blood  or  other  normally  sterile  body  fluid samples taken from a patient suspected of having bacteraemia.

13.5.2 Only  clinicians  who  have  been  given  specific  training  in  the  collection  of specimens for blood cultures and assessed as competent should perform this phlebotomy procedure. Only these suitably trained individuals are able to request this test on the Pathology Electronic Ordering System.
13.5.3 Broomfield Hospital document reference ‘Blood Culture Guidelines'; register number 07036 must be used when undertaking this process.

13.5.4 BacT/ALERT Blood Culture bottles are ready for use. Store protected from direct sunlight at room temperature (15-30ºC). An expiry date is printed on each bottle label. Do not use the culture bottles beyond the last day of the month indicated.

13.5.5 Great care must be taken to prevent contamination of the patient sample during venepuncture and during inoculation in to culture bottles. Contamination could lead to a specimen being determined positive when a clinically relevant isolate is not actually present. This leads unnecessary waste of Microbiology resources and the inappropriate use of antibiotics.
13.5.6 Obtain blood samples prior to initiating antibiotic therapy. If this is not possible, blood should be drawn immediately before administering the next antibiotic dose.

13.5.7 Use disposable gloves and handle inoculated bottles cautiously as though capable of transmitting infectious agents. Consult the Occupational Health Department immediately if materials are ingested or come into contact with open lacerations, lesions or other breaks in skin (including needle stick injury).

13.5.8 Blood cultures must be delivered directly to the Microbiology Department during 08:00-17:00 on weekdays and at all times on the weekend. They should only be left in a designated tray at Pathology Reception D228 out-of-hours between 17:00 and 8:00 on weekdays. Porters should then collect those left overnight and deliver them to Microbiology around 08:15 the following morning. There is no longer an Incubator required to place the Blood Culture bottles in at any time by Broomfield Hospital staff including Portering.
13.5.9 Under no circumstances should they be transported in the Pneumatic Vacuum Delivery System.
13.5.10 Delays in transporting these samples to the Microbiology Department will cause false negative results.

Minimum labelling criteria

14.1.1 Label the sample clearly with the patient's surname and first name, date of birth, date and point of collection (e.g. ward, OPD) and time - particularly important for serial sampling in dynamic function tests and tryptase measurements.

14.1.2 The  Information  Standards  Board  for  Health  and  Social  Care  published  the standard ISB 0149 which mandates the use of the NHS number to identify people receiving health and care services.
14.1.3 Both the specimen and form should be signed (refer to point 12.2).

14.1.4 To protect the patient; departments will not process unlabelled, incorrectly labelled or  incorrectly  collected  samples.  At  least  three  patient  identifiers,  first  name, surname, date of birth, hospital number or NHS number will normally be required. Any variations from this policy will require direct communication with the individual department. Results
Interpretation of results and measurement of uncertainty.

Reports issued by the laboratory will generally have a reference range alongside the result. These may vary according to the patients' age or gender but other factors may also affect the result interpretation: The measurement of uncertainty has  been  calculated  for  all  assays,  for  further information  please  contact  the relevant laboratory.
16.1.1  Pre-examination factors

Sample handling can affect results of certain analytes. For example bilirubins and porphyrins are destroyed by exposure to light and haemolysis increases serum levels of potassium and phosphate. Certain analytes vary according to the patients' state – e.g. triglycerides and glucose are higher in the non-fasted (random) state than when the patient has fasted prior to sample collection. In addition there are a number of analytes which demonstrate variability depending on the time of day that the sample is collected. Cortisol for example reaches a peak at 9 am and falls to its lowest point at midnight.

6.1.2 Certain analytes are affected by prescription (and non-prescription) drugs. Commonly used anti-epileptic medications are known to have in vivo effects GGT and ALP and oral contraceptives will affect LH/FSH levels for example.
16.1.3 Examination factors

Analytical variation describes random variation due to assay imprecision. All analysis is subject to a degree of random variation which is generally predictable and can be quantified. This degree of variation varies according to the type of assay and is generally less for highly automated biochemistry assays (e.g. analytical imprecision for sodium is approximately 1%) compared to more complex immunoassays (e.g. 5% for TFTs). Certain drugs may also directly affect analyses – for example some steroids cross react in our cortisol assay and may cause an apparent increase or decrease in the measured value.
16.1.4 Post-examination factors

Interpretation of results should take into account the biological differences between individuals. For example serum ALP is higher in pregnancy and in childhood, and serum creatinine and CK is higher in those of Afro-Caribbean ethnicity compared to Caucasians.

16.1.5 When interpreting any laboratory results it is important that factors such as those outlined above are considered. When monitoring a patients disease or clinical status it is important to consider how large a result change should be before it is considered significant. This value is known as the reference change value and is derived from knowledge of the analytical and biological variation. For example, for serum sodium a change of more than 4% between two values is required before the change can be considered significant, whilst for serum creatinine the value is approximately 13%.

16.1.6 This is a complex subject and a comprehensive account cannot be given here. However it is important to consider the uncertainty of measurement when interpreting laboratory data. If advice is needed on result interpretation or factors which may affect your patients' results, please contact the Consultant or Principal Clinical Scientist who will be happy to assist you with your query.
Each department has established which abnormal results require urgent attention; these results will be telephoned to the requestor.
When telephoning results, staff are instructed to take the name and job title of the person to whom they are giving the result.
All telephoned results must be repeated back to avoid errors.
Results are released from the laboratory in electronic or paper formats.

Broomfield Hospital offers an electronic results package called Review to provide access  to  Pathology  results.  Access  and  training  for  this  system  is  available through the Broomfield Hospital IT helpdesk.
The measurement of uncertainty has been calculated for all quantitative tests or those which include a measurement step and is available upon request from the relevant laboratory.

Histopathology
Routine histology specimen details
19.1.1 Normal turnaround times:
Small biopsies:  7 days;
Large specimen: 10 working days (unless requiring decalcification).
19.1.2 Please be aware that additional investigations such as immunohistochemistry and molecular testing may be required, which may lengthen the required turnaround time.

19.1.3 10% formal saline fixative solution must be used for all routine histology specimens. An adequate amount of fixative should be used to completely cover the specimen (10x specimen volume). Inadequate fixation will result in poor morphology which may affect interpretation, any further tests and delay the report turnaround time.
19.1.4 A clearly labelled appropriate sized container must be used. The lids must be correctly fitted and sealed.
19.1.5 Small specimen pots should be placed in a clear sealed bag and the form enclosed in the attached open sleeve to avoid any contamination from leaking fluid.
19.1.6 A completed request form must accompany the specimen, clearly stating patient details; source; consultant and clinical history.

19.1.7 All samples must clearly specify the anatomical site from which they have been taken and include a full clinical history. Full clinical details are required for histopathological consultation and failure to provide can lead to delays in reporting or even misleading results.
19.1.8 Any high risk specimens should be identified as such.
19.1.9 All urgent specimens should be clearly marked on the request form and the laboratory notified of its arrival.
19.1.10 GP specimens need the pot labelling with patient details etc., as well as the attached request form.
19.1.11 Products of Conception/ Placentas:

Products of Conception (POCs) where there is a failed pregnancy, specimens should be received in 10% formalin, in a suitably sized pot, and accompanied by a completed disposal consent form. Specimens received without a consent form will be processed but chased for consent. If after 6 months, no consent form has been received, the specimen will be disposed of by the department in accordance with the Trust and HTA guidelines;
POCs post live birth are considered retained placental tissue and do not require consent for disposal;
Identifiable placentas must be accompanied by a completed placenta triage request form, regardless of the fate of the baby.
19.1.12 Testicular biopsies for infertility investigations should be sent in Bouins fixative, which is available from the laboratory (ext.).
19.1.13 Skin biopsies for immunofluorescence need to be placed directly in Michel's fluid (available from the department, ext. 6794) and sent to the laboratory.

19.1.14 Specimens from left and right breasts on the same patient should be sent with separate request forms to avoid confusion. Multiple margins need to be clearly labelled and written on the request form for clarification.

19.2.1 These samples are sent to St Bartholomew's for processing.
19.2.2 The final report when received back to the laboratory is forwarded to the clinical team.

19.3.1 Authorised results are available on the Broomfield Hospital Review system in all clinical areas (including out of hours).

19.3.2 All reports are sent to the appropriate medical secretary for filing in the patient's notes, so please check Broomfield Hospital Review and with the medical secretary before telephoning the laboratory.
19.3.3 It is strongly advised that sufficient time is allowed for a report to be ready before making a follow up appointment (> one week), unless the specimen is clinically urgent.

19.3.4 Pre-authorisation verbal reports can only be conveyed to the appropriate senior clinician directly by the reporting pathologist over the telephone. Histology clerical staff are not permitted to read out pre-authorisation reports over the telephone.

19.3.5 If a report is required for an off-site clinic, then a report can be emailed provided a secure mailbox can be provided (e.g. NHS.net). Again it is better to check results are available before the start of the clinic, rather than wait for the patient to be present.

19.4.1 Turnaround time: 30 minutes from receipt for an intra-operative opinion.

19.4.2 All frozen sections must be booked at least  hours in advance with the laboratory (ext.) with approval from the Consultant Histopathologist. Please arrange for any cases requiring frozen sections to be early on the theatre list, in case there are any complications or the operation is longer than anticipated.
19.4.3 Previous relevant clinical history is required when booking cases and any referred patients with biopsy results from another hospital must be faxed with frozen section booking.

19.4.4 If there is a risk of infection then it is not possible to carry out a frozen section (TB or hepatitis B or C) unless absolutely essential for patient care. The risk must be clearly indicated on the form for staff safety and a contact number.
19.4.5 A pathologist may not be available at short notice but it is appreciated that occasionally unpredicted findings may arise in theatre, which requires a frozen section.
19.4.6 The specimen must be sent to the laboratory dry,  clearly labelled and with completed request and ‘chain of custody' forms, stating the theatre extension for the result.
19.4.7 Please notify the laboratory once the specimen has left theatre, in case it is delivered to the wrong place, and state if more specimens are to follow.
19.4.8 Multiple pots need to be clearly identified as to site etc.

data.text: Mortuary
Procedures in the event of a patient's death

22.1.1 Bereavement;  A  Doctor  who  has  seen  the  patient  in  their  last  illness  must complete the Medical Certificate of Cause of Death “MCCD”. Put GP details and patient details on the system and then fax a notice of death to the patient's GP.
22.1.2 House officers should make themselves available to talk to the close relatives of the deceased.
22.1.3 A doctor who saw the patient in their last illness and within 14 days of death is responsible for issuing the MCCD.

22.1.4 The doctor who completes the MCCD should complete Cremation Form 4 when required to do so. This is not a necessity, but it does expedite the process to have the same doctor complete both forms.

22.1.5 The Cremation Form 5 can only be completed by a medical practitioner who must be fully registered for at least 5 years and hold a licence to practise within the meaning of the Medical Act 1983.
22.1.6 Deaths occurring in the following circumstances should be reported to H.M. Coroner.
No doctor saw the deceased during his or her last illness;
Although a doctor attended the deceased during the last illness, the doctor is not able or available, for any reason, to certify the death;
The cause of death is unknown;
The death occurred during an operation or before recovery from the effects of an anaesthetic;
The death occurred at work or was due to industrial disease or poisoning;
The death was sudden and unexplained;
The death was unnatural;
The death was due to violence or neglect;
The death was in other suspicious circumstances; or
The death occurred in prison, police custody or another type of state detention.
Reference: Guide to Coroner Services https://www.coronersociety.org.uk/_img/pics/pdf_1503323588.pdf

22.1.7 Post mortems on known high risk cases (Biohazard Category 3; such as HIV, Hepatitis B, etc.) will only be carried out by fully qualified senior anatomical pathology technologists (APTs). Trainee APTs will not have involvement in these cases.
22.1.8 Category 4 cases (Such as viral haemorrhagic fevers) will not have post mortems carried out. These will be done in a specialist centre and no APTs should have involvement with these patients.

22.1.9 If blood tests are required to confirm the presence of an infection, then consent must be sought from the next of kin (NOK) or the coroner before being obtained. If admission bloods have not been tested for the suspected infection, it will require consent from the coroner before this can be retained and tested.

22.1.10 Once a post mortem has been requested, relatives must give their consent as to how they wish the tissues taken for examination are to be disposed of. It is the responsibility of the Coroner's Officers to obtain this consent as soon as possible, using the forms available. A time limit of 3 months has now been added for a reply to be received by the Coroner's Officers, after which the specimen can be discarded by the laboratory, according to their protocols.

Swabs with transport medium are supplied for all wound swab uses. The medium is designed for bacterial maintenance and is unsuitable for chlamydia and virus investigations. Swabs from dry skin lesions - e.g. impetigo, can be taken by first moistening the swab with sterile water. Superficial swabbing may lead to the overgrowth of skin organisms obscuring true pathogens, and aspirated pus or fluid are better specimens for infected wounds. Always state the site and nature of the wound. This is essential as the laboratory may need to interpret findings against a background of normal flora present in a given part of the body. If copious pus or exudate is present, aspirate with a sterile syringe and transfer to a sterile universal container. If insufficient to aspirate rotate a swab in the centre of the infected area and place the swab in the plastic transport sheath.

Bacterial swabs are set up in the laboratory to investigate for specific target pathogens dependent on the site of the swab and the clinical details provided. It is therefore vital to ensure that the correct sample type is requested and full clinical details provided on the request. Pus samples in plain universal are preferable to swabs of pus especially in deep seated infection sites. * Swabs from ulcers should be discouraged, preferred sample aspirate or biopsy. Empirical therapy may be required as culture results can take 6 days. Local protocols should be followed or contact medical microbiologist for advice if uncertain. Screening of Burns Unit patients should be done in line with local protocols and will be driven by where the burn injury is.

Per nasal swabs are used for the detection of Bordetella species (whooping cough). These are special wire swabs designed to reach the per nasal area Insert the swab into the nostril and guide it gently and horizontally to the back of the nose. If an obstruction is encountered, withdraw the swab and reinsert it through the other nostril. As soon as the resistance to the posterior wall is felt, withdraw the swab and insert it into container. Send the swab directly to the laboratory.

Cervical and high vaginal swabs must be taken with the aid of a speculum. It is important to avoid vulval contamination of the swab. If there are obvious candidal plaques swab the lesions. If pelvic infection, including gonorrhoea, is suspected, swab the cervical os. High vaginal swabs Introduce the speculum. Roll the swab firmly over the surface of the vaginal vault. Place the swab in the plastic transport sheath. Cervical swabs Introduce the speculum; roll the swab in the endocervix. Place the swab in the plastic transport sheath. If Herpes simplex is suspected send an additional swab from the base of the lesion in virus transport medium. For Trichomonas, swab the posterior fornix using Aptima swabs (see below) For Chlamydia and Neisseria gonorrhoeae culture use Aptima swabs (see below).

Genital samples are indicated in patients where: recurrent thrush, vaginal pH < 4.5 consistent with BV or TV, vaginal pH > 4.5 who is > 60 years old or who has dyspareunia or dysuria Group B streptococcal screening in pregnancy

Observe aseptic technique when sampling fluids. Do not sample from drain bag or reservoir. Samples must be transported as quickly as possible as the recovery of anaerobes may be compromised if the transport of sample exceeds 3 hours. Note: Joint aspirates, pleural fluids, ascitic fluids and CAPD fluids should be inoculated directly into blood culture bottles following methodology described in Broomfield Hospital document 07036 (available on the intranet).

Fluid samples from sterile sites, e.g. ascitic fluid, peritoneal fluid, synovial fluid, pericardial fluid, amniotic and pleural fluid can detect organisms that may indicate potentially life threatening infections. If an urgent gram stain is required please contact the laboratory as Gram stains are not routinely undertaken.. Drain fluids may grow mixed bacteria and results will be authorised to indicate clinical significance.
